ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
N/A
Just virtual seminar
NA
Virtual seminar

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned to synthesize historical texts about commodities in colonial Africa and have a discussion about them. I extensively studied the social, economic, and ecological impact of the ivory, rubber, cotton, and diamond industries on Africa and the world markets. I learned to write a historical research paper using primary and secondary sources.

Out of all of the courses I've taken at Yale, I probably learned the most in this class. I learned so much not only about the history of colonialism on the African continent, but how globally connected the sale of so many commodities are.

I learned about colonial and post-colonial African history through the lens of several different resources: ivory, rubber, cotton, and diamonds. The writing  assignments allowed us to synthesize primary and secondary historical sources. The reading  were all very interesting and thoughtfully selected.

I learned to read and analyze historical sources.
I learned to be able to research and construct a 12 page final paper on a particular commodity in Africa.
An understanding of the histories and global impact of 4 different commodities of colonialism that were influential to African history.
I learned a lot about the history of various commodities in Africa, which included learning the history of the countries from which those commodities were sources.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Harms is so kind and passionate about this subject that it made our conversations interesting despite the inability to meet in person.
I really liked the readings, but it would have been great to read more sources by African authors.

No weaknesses.

Great course all around.
Strengths: well organized, very interesting material, diverse readings (mixture of primary and secondary sources), diverse authorship
The course readings are very varied and in-depth; discussion was often rather vague but I suspect this was a product of the virtual seminar format making it difficult to get settled.

Strengths: the reading list, which was fantastic. (In particular, I loved "Empire of Cotton.") I liked hearing from my classmates about their discussion papers. I also liked doing research for my final paper; Professor Harms was a fantastic resource and recommended great books about my topic.

Weaknesses: Perhaps it was a function of the virtual classroom, but I found class discussion to be a bit stilted. A friend told me that last year Professor Harms had a TA help lead discussion, which I think would've been great.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom can never replace in person classes. But Professor Harms was very understanding about the limitations of being away from campus and the resources taken away from us this year. The Professor did everything he could to help us. It could be improved obviously by meeting in person, but I understand thats not recommendable at this moment.
I liked how Professor Harms didn't force a conversation. He does a really good job of noting when students will direct a conversation on their own and when it's time to move on to the next topic.

Pretty good class. Zoom worked well for discussions.

In zoom, discussions/seminars > lectures.
The reduced class time helped immensely. I don't think I would have gotten as much from the course if it were the full 110 minutes.
Course  was  conducted in live seminar format. Small class size  help discussion flow rather normally

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Ive never taken a history class that focuses on commodities, so if you are interested in the intersection between history, environmental studies, anthropology, and economics, please take this class!
Yes! You will learn so much. If you are interested in the history of capitalism, economics, African studies, or colonialism, definitely take this course!

Yes, please do! Professor Harms is so nice and knowledgeable, and the seminar (even via Zoom) is very engaging. The readings are well-selected and give both background information and in-depth accounts of African commodities. Papers aren't super long and you have so much flexibility with the final paper.
Yes, fantastic teacher, fantastic topic, great as a seminar. Also people should take more seminars.
Yes! great course to take if you are interested in the topics. Harms is the best
If you love colonial African history, there's certainly to be something in here you'll enjoy! It's somewhat of a niche course but brilliant if you like that niche

Yes, I think the course offered a great introduction to a topic not often addressed in other history courses: the history of the commodities trade. Professor Harms was a great guide as he knows a lot about the course material.
